PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY:
Ringneck provides safety training to its employees and contractors on an annual basis. Any changes to improve safety will be implemented immediately upon discovery of needed changes.

has a catchment basin with underground piping to secondary containment of the tank farm. For this scenario, passive and active mitigation was not considered, as the mitigation strategies currently in place would not contain a vapor cloud fire. RMP Comp was used to determine the alternative distance to endpoint; the model results were 0.1 miles, and the model output is also included as part of the backup documentation maintained onsite. Population data was obtained using Circular Area Profiling Software (CAPS) which incorporates 2020 U.S. Census Data. Public receptor information (i.e., schools, hospitals, etc.) was obtained using Google Earth and Bing, as well as the facility’s knowledge of nearby residences. No environmental receptors are affected by an alternative release of denaturant.

The Ringneck facility qualifies as a Program 3 due to the presence of the flammable mixture that is covered by the Process Safety Management requirements.


GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS:
Please review the first section of this Executive Summary for the general accidental release prevention program information.

Ringneck’s maintenance department performs regular preventative maintenance inspections, as required by the manufacturer's recommendations and/or State and Federal regulations. Monthly visual inspections are conducted, and monthly leak detection monitoring is performed, with associated reports filed per South Dakota Department of Agriculture and Natural Resources (DANR) and/or EPA requirements.

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY:
There have been no reportable accidents associated with RMP-covered processes at the Ringneck facility in the past five years.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM:
The Ringneck ethanol plant has several safety programs in place at the facility that incorporate emergency response. Ringneck has evacuation and response procedures for fires, explosions, spills, etc. outlined in the facility Emergency Action Plan

rates 24 hours per day, seven (7) days per week to manufacture ethanol by fermentation from corn. The regulated substance under the RMP program is a flammable mixture - natural gasoline (also known as denaturant).

WORST CASE AND ALTERNATIVE CASE SCENARIOS:
Worst Case Scenarios:

1.	Flammable Mixture (Denaturant): The flammable mixture stored onsite is natural gasoline, typically referred to as denaturant. Natural gasoline is used onsite to denature ethanol prior to shipment offsite. Denaturant is stored in an aboveground steel tank in the facility tank farm. The tank is located in a diked containment structure that contains an impermeable liner with gravel overlay. A worst case SDS was used to determine RMP applicability. The worst-case scenario used is the release of the entire contents of the denaturant tank, causing a vapor cloud explosion. RMP Comp was used to determine the worst-case distance to endpoint; the model results yielded a 0.8 mile radius, and is provided as part of the backup documentation maintained onsite. Population data was obtained using Circular Area Profiling Software (CAPS) which incorporates 2020 U.S. Census Data. Public receptor information (i.e., schools, hospitals, etc.) was obtained using Google Earth and Bing, as well as the facility’s knowledge of nearby residences. No environmental receptors are affected by a worst-case release of denaturant.

Alternative Scenario:

1. Flammable Mixture (Denaturant): The alternative scenario used for the flammable mixture is the release of natural gasoline due to a tanker truck loadout spill, causing a vapor cloud fire. The endpoint used was an over pressurization of 1.0 pounds per square inch (psi), a worst-case option. Denaturant deliveries at the facility are not limited to regular business hours but occur with a facility staff member in the control room overseeing loadout operations - therefore a release at the loadout area could be ceased within minutes by manual overrides. The loadout area also

RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
Ring-Neck Energy & Feed, LLC

Ringneck Energy & Feed, LLC (Ringneck) is an existing ethanol production facility in Onida, South Dakota. Ringneck began operations at the facility in April 2019. There has been no change in management since the start of operations.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND RESPONSE POLICIES:
Ringneck has an ongoing commitment to the health and safety of onsite employees and the surrounding community. This commitment is demonstrated in the resources invested in accident prevention, such as personnel training for the proper operation and maintenance of plant equipment and preventative maintenance programs.

Ringneck has emergency response policies in place that are addressed in the facility's Health and Safety Plan; Industrial Storm Water Pollution Prevention Plan; Spill Prevention, Controls, and Countermeasures Plan; and Emergency Action Plan. Most of the listed Plans require a minimum of annual training in order to keep employees educated on emergency response procedures in place at the facility. All new employees are required to undergo training on emergency response procedures prior to initiating responsibilities onsite.

Ringneck’s policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances. However, if a release does occur, plant personnel will respond to contain the release as necessary.

The primary emergency coordinator for Ringneck is Mike Stanley, Plant Manager. His work and 24-hour emergency response telephone numbers are provided in the Registration Section of this document. The following individual (with associated work and 24-hour emergency response telephone numbers) assists the Plant Manager with RMP and spill response coordination:

Aaron Trabing, EHS Manager
Work: 605.945.6987
24-Hour: 307.851.6498
